Clinical record keeping standards policy / MSEPO-20239/1.1

Introduction

Clinical record keeping is an integral part of high quality treatment and care and fundamental to patient care and communication between healthcare professionals. It is essential that those who use health records understand the ethical concepts of professional practice which relate to them e.g. the need to protect confidentiality, to assist patients to make informed decisions, to ensure informed consent. Ensuring the legibility, organisation and completeness of health records is an essential component of professional clinical practice.

All healthcare professionals have a responsibility to record accurate information about the care they are providing. All professional organisations expect that high quality standards of care are delivered and maintained and this must include record keeping. The standard of record keeping reflects, and is an indication of professional practice.

Failure to record information accurately in health records can have serious consequences for patients and their relatives. These failures may result in reduced quality of care and litigation. Poor record keeping is a major factor in litigation cases brought against NHS organisations.
Good quality record keeping:
Promotes high standards of clinical care by acting as a tool for assessment, treatment and care delivery;
Minimises the likelihood of delays or inappropriate care;
Provides an accurate record of the planning, delivery and treatment of care;

Provides an accurate and complete record of communication between health care professionals, the patient and their relatives and carers and promotes effective communication that delivers continuity of care between members of the multidisciplinary health care team;
Demonstrates that care follows evidence-based guidance or evidences variances including decisions not to treat;
Acts as a record of any problems that have arisen such as changes in the patient's condition and actions taken as a result;
Provides the Clinical Coding Team with the information required for accurate
coding.
Scope
This policy applies to both written and electronic patient health records and applies to all staff who record patient information, including locum, bank and agency staff.

The policy describes the basic record-keeping standards that all staff groups are required to adhere to when contributing to health records of patients under the care of the Trust. The standards set out in this policy do not replace standards set by professional organisations but are complementary to them.
The purpose of this policy is to clarify staff responsibilities for the accurate and timely records of patient health records and information given to patients, set the
standards the Trust expects staff to comply with and identify the monitoring arrangements for the standard of documentation within the patient health records.
In addition, implementation of the policy addresses the requirements of the NHS Digital Data Security and Protection Toolkit annual assessment.

The policy does not describe the standard design of paper records. For further information refer to the Management of new health records documentation procedure (Basildon Hospital), policy for Trust and MSE documentation (Southend Hospital) or Health records policy (Broomfield Hospital).
Definitions

table_items.text: All information recorded by Trust employees as part of the processes for the clinical management of a patient. This includes both paper based and electronic formats. Health records are also known as the ‘patient medical record' and the ‘patient clinical record'.

Senior Information Risk Owner is the Chief Information Officer who acts as an advocate for information risk on the Board and in internal discussions, and will provide written advice to the Accountable Officer on the content of their annual Statement of Internal Control (SIC) in regard to information risk.
Any electronic system that holds clinical information including notes, prescribing and diagnostic information

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Information Governance Steering Group – has the responsibility to ensure that this document is reviewed and updated in line with timeframe or in response to any legislative, national or professional standard changes.
Risk and Compliance groups will receive clinical audit reports of compliance with record keeping standards and are responsible for agreeing associated actions.
Chief Medical Officer is the designated Board Member for Patient Safety and has overall accountability for the management of health records.
Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) – has the responsibility of ensuring that data protection issues are brought to the Board for discussion as required.

Associate Director, Risk and Compliance has the responsibility to review this policy regularly against any legislative, national or professional standards changes and to ensure this policy is in keeping with the information governance toolkit requirements.
Corporate Nursing, Divisional Directors, Clinical Directors, Heads of Nursing, Associate Directors of Nursing, Matrons, Chief Pharmacist
To promote high standards of clinical record keeping within their area of responsibility in accordance with this policy.
To support participation in the planned documentation audit and ensure the audit report is disseminated within their area.
To ensure action plans to address deficiencies in clinical record keeping identified by audit are reviewed at departmental meetings including Directorate Governance Meetings on a regular basis.
Ward and Department Managers:
Ensure that clinical record keeping in their area is of the standard defined in this policy.
Ensure participation in the annual audit and dissemination of findings to staff.
Review audit reports and the relevant action plan addressing identified deficiencies.
Ensure that any incidents that arise with regard to clinical record keeping are reported and managed in accordance with the Incident Policy.
Maintain a regularly updated register of names and signatures

All registered healthcare professionals involved in clinical care – have the responsibility of keeping clear, legible, accurate and contemporaneous health records which record all the relevant clinical findings, any decisions made, information given to patients and any drugs or other treatment prescribed.

They also have the responsibility of ensuring that where students or non-registered staff under their supervision completes clinical documentation, that this meets the standards detailed in this policy. Entries should be appropriately countersigned to confirm entries have been checked.

Students and other unregistered staff – Pre-registration students, health care assistants and other unqualified staff may make entries in the health record where appropriate, but they should be supervised and deemed as competent to make entries by the registered practitioner they are working with at the time. In addition, their entries must be countersigned and checked by an appropriate registered practitioner.

Dietetic Assistants - are not directly supervised by a Registered Dietician but report back to the appropriate Registered Professional on a weekly/daily/monthly basis and may make un-supervised entries in the patient health record.

Dietetic students who are in their ‘Consolidation placement' 3C, i.e. have taken their final exam and have been deemed as competent by their Registered Supervisor at the Trust and personal tutor at University by means of discussion and assessment at the HEI, may make un-countersigned entries in the Patient Health Record. The Registered Supervisor's name must be included in the entry in the Patient Health Record and on the Dietetic record cards. These students will be
subject to daily assessment of their entries by their Registered Supervisor at the end of the working day.

All staff involved in recording/retrieving patient information - have the responsibility to complete an electronic incident form wherever information is illegible, missing or documented inappropriately.

Staff who are employed by another organisation - Staff who are employed by another organisation but who are directly involved in patient management i.e. Social Services may also record information in the patients' record, provided such entries are made in a timely, clear, legible and accurate manner.
Clinical audit team – are responsible for monitoring record keeping through the clinical audit programme.
Record Keeping Standards
Legal obligation and good practice
5.1.1 The Trust is committed to managing the risks associated with clinical record keeping, facilitating the delivery of safe and effective care. Therefore all health records must be:
Clear, accurate and legible;
Chronological and made contemporaneously;
Attributable;
Relevant;
Suitably frequent.

5.1.2 The primary function of health records is to facilitate continuity of care and to act as a tool for communication. Good record keeping allows a clear picture of events to be obtained which is vital for legal decision making and on-going care planning.
5.1.3 Patient health records are sometimes required as evidence in order to investigate a complaint at local level or for criminal proceedings or claims.
5.1.4 Records must be objective and worthy of independent scrutiny. In the event of an investigation their content can be critical.
5.1.5 The approach to record keeping that courts of law adopt tends to be ‘If it has not been recorded, it has not been done'.
Patient identification

5.2.1 It is essential that all patient details are accurately identified on all clinical documentation that forms part of the health record (including electronic records). Each separate page in the health record should include patient's name, NHS number and hospital number, date of birth and location in the hospital. The patient identifiers must be the NHS and hospital number wherever these are known but may be the ED card number where the NHS or hospital number is not known.
5.2.2 Pre-printed bar-coded identification labels may be used and will contain name, address, hospital number, NHS number, date of birth and date.
5.2.3 The primary patient identifier is always the NHS/Hospital number and this must be recorded on every page created.
Date and time on each entry

5.3.1  Each entry must record the date (using the format DD/MM/YY) and time of the entry (24 hour clock) and the time that any consultation occurred. Entries made to electronic records will usually be date and time stamped at the point of entry.
Timeliness of entries
5.4.1 All entries must demonstrate a clear chronology of events and must be in chronological order within speciality.
5.4.2 The discharge record / discharge summary should be commenced at the time a patient is admitted to hospital.
5.4.3 An entry must be made in the patient's health record whenever they have been seen by a health professional.

5.4.4 Doctors should make an entry in the health record at least every 24 hours for inpatient admissions. When there is no doctor's entry for 48 hours or longer (for example, if it has been decided that the patient does not need to be seen over the weekend), the Doctor making this decision should explain why.

5.4.5 From a nursing / midwifery perspective entries will be made at least 3 times a day, morning, afternoon and night. If staff are working a long day – 07:30 – 21:00 – 2 entries will be made to reflect the different times of day. An entry will be made of any and all changes in the patient condition. To escalate any concerns the SBAR form should be used.
5.4.6 Health records must be written contemporaneously providing current information on the care and condition of the patient. An entry must not be made in advance (unless it is a plan).
5.4.7 Where entries are made much later than the event being described it must clearly state that the entry has been written in retrospect (see below).
5.4.8 Entries must NEVER be backdated and must always be dated and timed for when the entry was made.
Omissions and retrospective entries
5.5.1 At times it may be necessary to make an entry that is late (out of sequence) or provide additional documentation to supplement or clarify entries previously written.

5.5.2 When a pertinent entry has been missed, requires further clarification or is not written in a timely manner, an appropriate entry must be used to record the information within the health record.

5.5.3 Any retrospective entries on documentation for inpatients should only be made in unusual or extenuating circumstances prior to scanning / filing of the documentation. Such entries should only be made before the end of the shift or day in question. It must be made clear that the entry is retrospective and the reason for the late entry recorded.

5.5.4 Retrospective information which needs to be added to the record should be entered as the next chronological entry using the current date and time (24 hour clock) and reference made to the date to which it relates.
Authentication of entries and methods of authentication
5.6.1 Every entry in the health record should identify the most senior healthcare professional present (who is responsible for decision making) at the time the entry is made.
5.6.2 Every entry in the health record must be authenticated (signed) by the author. As this occurs at ‘log on' for electronic records it is imperative staff do not share passwords.

5.6.3 The authentication for handwritten entries must include a signature, printed name, grade and bleep number (where relevant) of the author. If there are two people with the same surname making entries within the health record then they must both use their full signature and printed name.
5.6.4 Initials must never be used where a signature is required by law e.g. legal forms.
5.6.5 Entries made by agency staff must incorporate detail of their employer.

5.6.6 In nursing notes at MEHT, the signatory sheet or first entries for each patient during a shift must be signed with printed name and designation recorded. All entries thereafter must be initialled. For nursing notes at Basildon Hospital and Southend Hospital every entry must include a signature and full printed name.
5.6.7 All users of care pathway documents must sign the sample signature sheet that is part of the documentation and each entry must show the date and time that the entry has been made.

5.6.8 The use of rubber stamps, including name and grade stamps is permitted but must in all circumstances be accompanied by a signature of the member of staff concerned. The stamp must only ever be used by the owner.

5.6.9 If record keeping is delegated to a student nurse then the record must be countersigned by a registered nurse. Signatures must be used not initials. Health professionals must clearly countersign the signature of any student who is being supervised in the administration of medicines.
Handover, referral and discharge

5.7.1 On each occasion where the consultant responsible for the patient's care changes, the name of the new responsible consultant and the date and time (24 hour clock) of the agreed transfer of care, should be recorded.

5.7.2 If a patient is transferred to a new ward/location, the first clinical entry after the transfer should state the date and time of transfer, and the new location. If a change in the consultant in charge of care has occurred with the change of location, this should also be noted.
5.7.3 The need for referral to specialist practitioners with necessary knowledge and skills to meet needs must be documented. A note of the date and time of referral will be made.
5.7.4 When a patient is discharged, medical staff must ensure the discharge forms, either electronically or paper format are completed.
Error correction

5.8.1 Health record entries must not be erased. Justifiable alterations or additions may be made if dated, timed (24 hour clock) and signed and clearly attributable to a named person in an identifiable role in such a way that the original entry can be read clearly.
5.8.2 Draw a single line through the entry. Make sure that the inaccurate information is still legible.
5.8.3 Do not alter or obliterate the original entry by blacking out with marker or by using correction fluid or writing over it.
5.8.4 Document the correct information.
5.8.5 Electronic systems have their own arrangements for correcting errors and users must contact the system managers for guidance.
Legibility
5.9.1 All entries must be legible. Entries must be readable to ensure continuity of care and give an account of each episode of care.
5.9.2 Handwritten entries must be made in black or dark blue ink so that, if necessary they can be reproduced for legal purposes. The important factor is that the entry is not faint or ‘spidery'.
5.9.3 Where barcoded forms are available, do not write on or near the barcode and do not use versions without a barcode.
5.9.4 Do not obscure writing with anything affixed to the healthcare records
5.9.5 Contributions from pharmacy staff may be made in green ink.
Specificity, objectivity and completeness
5.10.1 Language used must be specific, not vague or generalised. Clinical staff must bear in mind that patients have access to their records under the Data Protection Act.

5.10.2 Document all facts and relevant information related to an event or course of treatment. Include the condition of the patient, their response to care and any deviation from the standard treatment.
5.10.3 Make sure the entry is complete and contains all the significant information. If the entry is incomplete, follow the guidelines for corrections (see above).
Appropriateness of entries
5.11.1 All health care practitioners must use their professional judgement to decide what information is deemed relevant and significant to record.
5.11.2 All practitioners must conform to individual codes of professional practice and to the Trusts Policy and related procedures.

5.11.3 The health record must only contain documentation that is relevant to the direct care of the patient. Health records should be free from statements that blame, accuse or compromise the patient, other professionals or the patients' family in any way. The health record must not record opinions on issues that are not related directly to clinical issues or clinical opinion.

5.11.4 All communication with and information given to patient/family/carers involvement in care should be documented within the health record. Details of any written information provided to the patient should be noted, including the title of the document and version number.
5.11.5 Variances / deviations from the planned care should be recorded when using integrated care pathways or core care plans.
Continuous entries

5.12.1  All entries must be documented in the next available space on the page. There should be no empty lines or blanks. There must be a continuous flow of information throughout the record with no gaps or spaces between documentation. If gaps are left accidentally they should have a line drawn diagonally through them. By ensuring that this process is followed will assist in ensuring a contemporaneous record of care is recorded and completed.
Use of abbreviations
5.13.1 Use of abbreviations should be avoided where possible and the risks associated with the use of abbreviations should be recognised.
5.13.2 For all therapists static or rotational within intermediate care services, no abbreviations are acceptable in the patients therapy notes - all notes must be written in full.
5.13.3 Only recognised abbreviations agreed by the department are to be included within the health patient record.
Clinical information on admission should include:
A written definitive or working diagnosis / reason for admission or referral;
An initial patient review including history of present condition, details of current medication, allergies, past medical history current relevant comorbidities and social history;
A record of initial physical examination;
Assessments;
Plans of care including any concerns, and the details of any action you have taken; information you have shared and decisions you have made relating to those concerns;
Treatment and or interventions given;
Progress notes, observations and consultation reports;
Results of investigations (for example, pathology, imaging, photographs);
Drug therapy records;
The appropriate completed consent form signed by the patient and health professional, where written consent is required;
Discharge arrangements;
Details of instructions relating to ‘do not resuscitate orders' and advanced directives;
A note of all untoward and unexpected events and any actions taken including discussions with patients and / or carers (refer to Incident and Being Open Policies);

Cause of death where death has occurred including record of notification to General Practitioner within 24 hours of death, post mortem where applicable. If a post mortem examination has been undertaken to ascertain the cause of death, a copy of the report must be included in the health records.
For patients undergoing surgery the health record will contain:
Details of valid  consent for patients undergoing surgery as detailed in the Consent policy;
A pre-operative diagnosis or indication for surgery/investigation made by a suitably qualified medical practitioner;
Confirmation that common complications and rare complications that may cause serious harm have been discussed with the patient prior to the procedure;
Operation, anaesthetic and re-admission records;
Discharge Care Planning documentation and communication;
Records of arrangements made for continuing care

Any material or items intentionally left in situ following surgery (e.g. packs, drains, mesh, surgical tape, haemostatic materials and other products) must be clearly documented within the healthcare record including the rationale and whether the items / material will subsequently be removed and the date for
removal.
Information Governance and security of records

5.16.1 All health records will maintain confidentiality of the information to be documented or recorded with no information on the outside of case notes other than the name and NHS number and / or hospital number. An alert sticker should be used to make staff aware of important information.

5.16.2 Ensure that any paper reports generated from the electronic systems are securely placed in the patient's health records in the designated sections and that printouts from monitoring and diagnostic equipment e.g. CTG, ECG are secured in accordance with the filing information printed on the inside back cover of the majority of patient's case notes.
Electronic Records
5.17.1 Electronic records should comply with the requirements above and processes must be in place to ensure:
5.17.2 All access to electronic clinical systems is as per the Information security policy
5.17.3 Staff must not share login details under any circumstances as this acts as a record of the identity of staff making the entry
5.17.4 The date and time of entries and identity of staff making the entry are recorded in the absence of a signature.

5.17.5 Where forms held electronically are completed on-line and published to the patient's electronic medical record (EMR), an audit stamp will be created against the created document which will contain the full user credentials for the authorised EMR use plus date and time created.

5.17.6 Any alteration or addition to the health record once the paper-work has been scanned on the Basildon system must be made by an (electronic) annotation within the EMR record. This function will only be available to authorised users. Any annotations will be shown as a speech bubble against the relevant part of the record and will automatically be populated with the name of the user currently logged on. The user must enter a date, time and their designation against their entry.
5.17.7 The annotation is held separately in the EMR and does not affect the integrity of the original image.
5.17.8 Misfiled documentation will be the responsibility of the team where the documentation was created.
Alert
5.18.1 All staff who become aware that there is a fact about a patient that must be made known to other staff involved in their care in the future must record an Alert by:
Fixing a red Alert (see inside front cover) sticker on the front cover of paper case notes and inputting the details of the alert on the inside front cover;
Or by requesting with the medical records team to add to the electronic medical record at Basildon Hospital or Lorenzo at Broomfield Hospital.
5.18.2 Alerts  may  be  required  for  any  of  the  following  purposes  with  details  of  any reactions documented if known - this list is not exhaustive:
Drug allergies;
Drug sensitivities;
Difficulties with certain procedures e.g. bloods, airways;
Patient has previously undergone blood transfusion;
Latex or other substance allergy;
A sensory impairment;
Presence of an advance directive “do not resuscitate” order;
A requirement for language interpretation or information or communication support needs;
One of a twin with the same initial;
Clinical trials.

5.18.3 It is unacceptable for any alert information to be detailed on the front cover of the records and staff who find that this has occurred must complete an incident form in accordance with the Incident Policy and return the records to the Health Records Centre for replacement.
Training Requirements
Training on the fundamental principles of good health record keeping is available to staff as part of the mandatory information governance training and on induction.
Monitoring and Audit
In order to ensure compliance with the standards and improve documentation of clinical information in health records, the Trust will undertake the following monitoring.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual/ department responsible for the monitoring
Group/committee/ forum which will receive the findings/ monitoring report
Committee/ individual responsible for ensuring that the actions are completed
Basic record- keeping standards used by all staff
Clinical Audit Team or clinical teams
Minimum annually for doctors, nurses and AHPs
Clinical Governance Committee (CGC) or equivalent and Directorate/Division Clinical Governance Groups

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy will be approved by the Information Governance Committee for each site. It will be disseminated via the monthly Trust Staff newsletter and will be available to staff on the Trust intranet. It is the responsibility of all staff who contribute to health records to make sure they have read a copy.

General Medical Council (2014) Keeping Records,
Royal College of Physicians (2007) Generic medical record-keeping standards
Nursing and Midwifery Council (2015) The Code: Professional Standards of Practice and Behaviour of Nurses and Midwives https://www.nmc.org.uk/standards/code/
Chartered Society of Physiotherapists –Service Standards for Practice 2005 (standard 19)
College of Occupational Therapists – COT 2010 http://www.cot.co.uk/sites/default/files/publications/public/code-of-ethics.pdf

Equality Impact Assessment

This policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment following the template used for all Trust policies. The result of the assessment demonstrates that no one as a consequence of this policy is placed at a disadvantage over others.
